oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Confederate "Ironclad" Armored Vessel
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Armored vessels; Warships; Ships; Flags
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Print of a Confederate "ironclad" steamship. Vessel is underway and is flying a Second National flag from her stern.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Poole, B.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This ship resembles the CSS Arkansas quite a bit but it is flying a Second National flag. However, the flag was adopted in May 1863 and the CSS Arkansas was destroyed in August 1862.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: St. John Guards Flag
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Military standards
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Company flag of St. John Guards. The names of the flag makers are embroidered on the stars.

The flag was made by Miss Anne E. Coleman, Miss Paralee Wood, Miss Helen Wood, Mrs. Fatima Sewell St. John, Mrs. St. John, Mrs. John Abraham Wood, Mrs. Fannie St. John, Miss Jennie St. John. It was raised at Woodbury (Tenn.) for a Confederate service. The flag was captured at Fort Donelson by the Federal Army. It was later returned to Woodbury. The flag is now in the State Museum.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Federal troop barracks
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Barracks
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Drawing of Federal troop barracks during the Civil War.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: E. M. Stark

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Battle of Stone River
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Stones River, Battle of, Murfreesboro, Tenn., 1862-1863; Rutherford County (Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Print of the Battle of Stones River depicting the Federal troops of General William Rosencrans fighting against Confederate troops under General Bragg. A Union column marches toward the action and a battery of cannon fires on Confederate troops as they charge.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Kurz & Allison
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Kurz and Allison was a well known Chicago firm specializing in colorful and dramatic chromolithograph prints of American historical events.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Fort Pillow Massacre
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers
United Stated - Hitory - Civil War, 1861-1865; Forrest, Nathan Bedford, 1821-1877; Fort Pillow, Battle of, Tenn., 1864; Lauderdale County (Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Print of the Fort Pillow Massacre showing General Forrest's Confederate troops firing and bayonetting the surrendering Federal force under Major William F. Bradford.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Kurz & Allison
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Kurz and Allison was a well-known Chicago firm specializing in colorful and dramatic chromolithograph prints of American historical events.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: General Beauregard silk ribbon
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Memorial works
Beauregard, G. T. - (Gustave Toutant), - 1818-1893
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Silk memorial ribbon picturing General Beauregard. Ribbon is white with crossed flags. One is the Confederate battleflag and the other is the Palmetto flag of South Carolina. A likeness of Beauregard is printed on the ribbon. Written on it is "In Memoriam Gen'l G.T. Beauregard Charleston's Gallant Defender."

Beauregard was a Confederate general who directed the first action of the Civil War (the bombardment of Ft. Sumter). He was second in command at First Bull Run and at Shiloh (assuming command when Johnston was killed). He died in New Orleans and is buried in Metairie Cemetery.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Cover page for W. W. Fergusson's "War Memories," Engineer Corps, P.A.C.S.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Flags
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; War Diaries
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Cover page of "War Memories" by W. W. Fergusson featuring calligraphied, stylized text for the title and hand-drawn, hand-colored Confederate and Federal flags.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Fergusson, W. W.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: William Wallace Fergusson was born in 1831. In 1861, he joined the Second Tennessee Regiment called the Sumner Greys and mustered into Conferderate service. He served at Shiloh and Chattanooga. He left service in May 1865 and returned to Smith County. He married Medora Kerby in 1866 and opened Blackgnat Academy at Riddleton which stayed in operation until the 1890s. He died in 1922. Civil War engineers built roads and bridges, planned defenses and prepared maps.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Plan of the military prison situated on Johnson's Island
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Prisons; Prisoners of war; Prison hospitals; Prison guards; Sutlers; Military medicine
Johnson Island Prison; Johnson Island (Ohio); United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Prisoners and prisons; United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 -- Maps
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Hand-drawn color map of the military prison at Johnson's Island in the bay of Sandusky, Ohio, where captured Confederate officers were held. Prison buildings and grounds are labeled. Drawn by Capt. J. T. Hogane, Topographical Engineer, C.S.A., Gen. M. Jeff Thompson's Division. In upper left corner: "James S. Brown, Major 46th Regt. Tenn. Vol., Capt'd at Island No. 10 April 8, 1862 By Genl Popes command. Block 2, Mess 2, Room 1."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hogane, Capt. James T.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Capt. James T. Hogane entered the service in August 1861. He was Brigade Engineer 1st District Missouri on staff of Brig. Gen. Thompson ("Co. Sappers & Miners"). He was captured on March 1, 1862, at New Madrid, Missouri, and came to be confined at Johnson's Island . He evidently used his talents to draw maps of the prison for various soldiers, such as James S. Brown. His handiwork is also seen at the front of St. Clair Morgan's Autograph Album in TSLA's Samuel Dold Morgan Papers.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Destruction of the Famous Confederate Privateer "Nashville"
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Ships
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Paddle steamers
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Print of the Federal Ironclad "Montauk" destroying the Confederate Privateer "Nashville" in the Ogeechee River. The "Montauk" is a low-profile inroclad steamship on the left, and the "Nashville," a converted passenger vessel, is in flames. Men can be seen in a rowboat at the bottom of the print, and a fort can be seen on the right of the print. Text from Captain Worden's report accompanies the image.
According to the March 28, 1863, edition of "Harper's Weekly," the crew of the "Montauk" fired fourteen shots at the "Nashville" and watched it sink.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Grand Concert by Morgan's Men Program
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Musicians; Concerts; Soldiers
United States - Hitory - Civil War, 1861-1865; Prisoner-of-war camps; Prisoners of War; Prisoners of war as musicians; Camp Douglas (Ill.); Concerts
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Drawing of three performers on stage, one with a violin, one with a banjo, and one dancing, advertising a concert to be performed by Confederate prisoners of war from John Hunt Morgan's cavalry at Camp Douglas. They appear to be performing the minstrel song "Old Robert Ridley." Text underneath describes the program.
Camp Douglas, Chicago, was a prisoner of war camp during the Civil War. Poor conditions in the camp eventually led to the deaths of more than six thousand prisoners.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Nashville and the camp of the Sixteenth Regiment of Ills. Vols. Inft. At Edgefield, Tennessee, circa 1863-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Maps; Military life
United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Nashville (Tenn.) -- Maps; Cumberland River (Ky. And Tenn.); United States. Army. Illinois Infantry Regiment, 16th
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: A pictorial representation in lithographic form of Nashivlle during the Civil War, with the camp of the Illinois 16th Volunteer Regiment at Edgefield in the foreground. The Cumberland River is seen in the background with gunboats and riverboats depicted. The state capitol building can be seen in the background overlooking the city of Nashville. Structures featured within the camp are the guard house, the headquarters, the hospital, the sutler, and the housing for the band.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Schrader, Theodore
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Most of the lithograph depicts camp activities as might be seen during the Civil War. The lithograph was created by Theodore Schrader of St. Louis, Missouri. The 16th Regiment Illinois Infantry was organized at Quincy, Illinois, and mustered in May 24, 1861. They marched from Tuscumbia, Alabama to Nashville from August 25 through September 15, 1862. They saw action at Columbia on September 10, 1862. They participated in the Siege of Nashville from September 15 through November 6 of 1862.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Proposed designs for gates and stone fence at Chattanooga Cemetery
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Cemeteries; Stone walls; Gates
Chattanooga National Cemetery; National cemeteries, American; Chattanooga (Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Three separate ink design drawings contained on one piece of coated fabric that relay sectioning, framing, and elevation in depicting proposed gates and stone fencing for the Chattanooga Cemetery. Scale is 1/2 inch to 1 foot.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: William Alonzo Wainwright, U.S. Assistant Quartermaster Records, 1861-1870
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: After the the Civil War, Wainwright stayed with the Quartermaster Department and helped oversee the location, identification, and re-interment of Union army dead in the National Cemeteries in Knoxcville, Murfreesboro, Chattanooga, and Atlanta. The burial of Union soldiers on the land that was to become the Chattanooga National Cemetery began on Nov. 25, 1863, under orders of General George Thomas. The Wainwright records are the second largest collection of extant Quartermaster records in the nation.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Let us Forgive but Not Forget, Sketch of Andersonville Prison, Stockade, and Hospital
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Tents; Prisoners; Dogs; Hospitals
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Andersonville National Historic Site (Ga.); Prisoner-of-war camps; Prisoners of War; Ex-Prisoners of war
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Drawing of life inside Andersonville Prisoner of War Camp. Large central image depicts events in the camp and are numbered with a legend beneath describing each. Images of specific events surround the central image.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: de la Baume, Felix

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Drawing of men loading a wagon by Francis Mohrhardt
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Drawings; Soldiers
Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Pencil drawing - 19th Century
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pencil drawing of four men, from Civil War era, loading a wagon near tents.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Francis Mohrhardt
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Francis Mohrhardt was an army engineer in the Tennessee Campaign during the U. S. Civil War. He served as a topographical engineer attached to the staff of General P. H. Sherman (1862-1863).

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Storming of Fort Donelson - Decisive Bayonet Charge of the Iowa Second Regiment of the Rebel Entrenchments
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Stewart County (Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Print showing Federal soldiers assaulting Confederate troops in the forest around Fort Donelson. Reverse of print has articles, poetry, and news columns.

Frank Leslie was an English-American engraver who published numerous periodicals. "Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper," later called "Frank Leslie's Weekly," was a popular magazine featuring prints, images and photographs of contemporary events.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Campaign in Tennessee: Bombardment of Fort Henry
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Ships; Rivers
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Fort Henry, Battle of, Tenn., 1862; Stewart County (Tenn.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Print shows the explosion of a large caliber gun defending Fort Henry from naval assault. Wounded soldiers and a flotilla of attacking naval ships can also be seen. Reverse of print has articles, poetry, and news columns.

Frank Leslie was an English-American engraver who published numerous periodicals. "Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper," later called "Frank Leslie's Weekly," was a popular magazine featuring prints, images, and photographs of contemporary events.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Sketch of Fort Delaware
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Prisons; Prisoners of war; Forts & fortifications; Military facilities
Fort Delaware (Del.); United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 --Prisoners and prisons
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Pencil sketch of one side of this prison for Confederate soldiers drawn by Dr. William Mark Eames, Federal surgeon. On the back of the image appears the notation, "Picture of Fort Deleware Del which Dr drew while there in 1864 guarding rebel prisoners."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Eames, Dr. William Mark
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Fort Delaware served as a harbor defense facility for the Delaware River beginning with the War of 1812. The pentagon-shaped fortification present during the Civil War had been constructed from 1848-1859 and was the largest fort in the country. Confederate prisoners and local Southern sympathizers were housed in wooden barracks on Pea Patch Island, not inside the fort itself. Most prisoners were captured at Gettysburg. The prison held forty thousand men by war's end; approximately 2,700 died there.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Grafted into the Army
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Sheet music covers; Music title pages; Music publishing industry; Songs; Patriotism
Root and Cady; Work, Henry C. (Henry Clay), 1832-1884
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Six-page sheet music entitled "Grafted into the Army." On the front cover is a mother holding a pair of torn trousers. Below is a young soldier walking picket duty.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Work, Henry C. (Henry Clay), 1832-1884
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Henry Clay Work (1832-1884) was an American songwriter and publisher. Before the war, he was an ardent abolitionist and Union supporter. A self-taught musician, he composed several popular songs. He is known as the "war poet." Root and Cady was a famous music publishing company based in Chicago. The company went out of business in 1871.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Stonewall Jackson's Last Words
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Sheet music covers; Music title pages; Music publishing industry; Songs; Ballads; Deathbeds; Generals
Jackson, Stonewall, 1824-1863; Confederate States of America; Meininger, J. C. (Julius C.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sheet music, entitled "Stonewall Jackson's Last Words." There is a sketch of the re-enactment of Jackson's last words.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Meininger, J. C. (Julius C.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Thomas J. (Stonewall) Jackson, a Confederate general during the Civil War, was probably the most well known commander next to General Robert E. Lee. Accidentally shot by a North Carolina regiment, he died of complications from pneumonia on May 10, 1863. Jules Meininger was a songwriter before and after the Civil War. He died circa 1911 in Nashville.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Star Spangled Cross and the Pure Field of White
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Sheet music covers; Music title pages; Music publishing industry; Patriotism
Flags; Selby, Julian A., b. 1833
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Four page sheet music includes a lithograph of a Confederate flag on the front cover.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Subaltern
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: George Dunn and Company was formed in 1863. He came to Wilmington, North Carolina, in early 1862. He later settled in Richmond, VA, where he was granted permission to print Confederate money and currency. He probably returned to Great Britain in early 1865. Julian A. Selby, a printer and newspaperman, lived in Columbia, South Carolina.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Sour Apple Tree, or Jeff Davis' Last Ditch
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Sheet music covers; Music title pages; Music publishing industry; Songs; Ballads
Davis, Jefferson, 1808-1889
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This is a folio-sized song, original Civil War period ballad by J. W. Turner about Jefferson Davis. The cover features a cartoon depicting Davis wearing a dress.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Turner, J. W.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Jefferson Davis was captured on May 10, 1865, at Irwinville in Irwin County, Georgia. After being captured, he was held as a prisoner for two years in Fort Monroe, Virginia.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Battle of Gettysburg
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Sheet Music covers; Songs; Ballads; Campaigns & battles; Battlefields
Gettysburg, Battle of, Gettysburg, Pa., 1863; Paull, E. T., 1858-1924
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Eight-page sheet music with a full color cover. On the cover is a color reproduction of Pickett's famous charge at Gettysburg. Companies selling this music are listed on the front cover.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Paull, E. T.
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Kenneth D. Rose Sheet Music Collection
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Edward Taylor Paull (1858-1924) was an American composer and music publisher. He composed and published music that was considered a rival of John Philip Sousa. He was known for his many marches and for his popular color-lithographed song sheet covers.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Old Contraband
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Sheet music covers; Music title pages; Songs; Ballads; Minstrel shows
Slavery; Slavery, abolition and emancipation
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sheet music, consisting of six pages, with an etching of an "African-American" representing the "Old Contraband." The composers are listed on the front cover.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Zieber, John L.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Contraband was a term commonly used in the United States during the Civil War to describe a new status for certain escaped slaves or those who came into the possession of Union forces. The Confiscation Act of 1861 declared any property used by the Confederate military, including slaves, could be seized by Union forces. By the end of the war in April 1865, an estimated ten thousand had applied to gain "contraband" status.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Bivouac of captured rebels on an island near Bridgeport, Tennessee [sic]
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Prisoners of war; Soldiers; Guards; Military camps; Campfires; Smoke; Trees

United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Bridgeport (Ala.); Tennessee River; United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865 - Prisoners and prisons; Railroads
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Image of captured Confederates on an island erroneously labeled near Bridgeport, Tennessee; the location is near Bridgeport, Alabama. The site is at the current CSX Bridge 122.6 over the Tennessee River Slough. Several clashes took place here due to the strategic, transportation, and communication importance of the site. Twice during the Civil War, the superstructure of the bridge was destroyed and rebuilt.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hiller
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Frank Leslie's Illustrirte Zeitung" was the German language version of his "Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper." The newspaper began operation in 1857 and ran until 1891. Through this publication, based in Pearl Street, New York, Leslie sought to serve the population of German immigrants. From 1830 to 1860, one and a half million Germans settled in the United States.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: "Capitol at Washington" stationery
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Stationery; Letterheads
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Bloomery Gap (Va.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Correspondence from a soldier to his wife. He writes of the need for news from home. In the upper left hand corner is a depiction entitled "Capitol at Washington" printed by Reagles & Co. of New York. There is mention of Gen. Landers, a Col. Tyler and Bloomery Gap, Virginia, in this letter
oai_dc:dc.dc:source: Tennessee Historical Society Civil War Collection

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Negro recruits taking the cars for Murfreesboro, Tenn., to join the Federal Army
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Recruiting & enlistment; Soldiers; Railroads
United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865 --Participation, African American; Tennessee -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Murfreesboro (Tenn.); Railroads
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This engraving features African Americans being guided onto a troop train headed for Murfreesboro where their wish to join the Federal Army will be granted. This illustration appeared in Frank Leslie's post-war volume "The Soldier in Our Civil War" (which has a number of editions), but it most probably premiered in "Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper" during the actual conflict. The origin of this colorized version is unclear.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Hillen, C. E. F.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: English-American engraver Frank Leslie informed ordinary Americans during the Civil War with his periodicals, such as "Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper" which contained remarkable wood-cut illustrations. His engravers illustrated volumes such as "The Soldier in Our Civil War" published after the war. C. E. F. Hillen was one of Leslie's artists who was badly wounded in the Atlanta Campaign. Two of Leslie's artists were captured and released by Lee, and one part-time artist, James O'Niell, was killed.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Star of Liberty
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Sheet music covers; Songs; Music
Confederate States of America - History
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "Star of Liberty" sheet music to Gov. I. G. Harris. Words written by Randel Weber. Music written by Dr. O. Becker. Entered according to Act of Congress, A. D.1861, by J. A. McClure, in the Clerks office of the District Court of Middle Tenn. C.S.A. J. Slinglandt, engraver and printer.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Bonnie Blue Flag
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Sheet music covers; Songs; Music
Confederate States of America - History; Geary, John White, 1819-1873
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: "The Bonnie Blue Flag" sheet music, dedicated to General John W. Geary and the Second Division, Twentieth Army Corps, United States Army. Entered according the Act of Congress A. D. 1864, by H. H. K. Elliott in the Clerks Office of the District Court of the Eastern District of Pennsylvania.

Information taken from inside cover: "The Bonnie Blue Flag" a Blue Flag, six feet square, with a white Star in the Centre, is the Battle or Field Flag of Gen. Geary's 2d division, 20th Corps, now in the Army of the Cumberland. This designation was ordered by General Hooker in his organization of the Army of the Potomac, to which the Division was then attached, in the Spring of 1863. The Rebels first saw the Flag at Chancellorsville, afterwards at Gettysburg, where it was recongnized by its old opponents.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: They Sleep in the South
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Sheet music covers; Songs; Music
Confederate States of America - History
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Sheet music titled "They Sleep in the South," music by Charles H. Levering.

The song is dedicated to the Mothers, Wives, and Sisters of the Noble Martyrs, who have heroically fallen in Defense of their Country. Music written by Chas. H. Levering. The words were written by W. W. Montgomery.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: View of the stockades and fortifications around the Capitol, Nashville, Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Capitols; Soldiers; Guards; Forts & fortifications; Military camps; Railroads; Cannons; Spectators; Public sculpture; Architecture; Lampposts
United States -- History -- Civil War, 1861-1865; Nashville (Tenn.); Sculpture; Architecture
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Image presents the juxtaposition of the beautiful architectutral features and sculpture exhibited in the east, or main fascade of the Tennesseee State Capitol Building with the surrounding heavy Federal stockades, fortifications, and general military occupation features.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Schell, Frederic B.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: During Federal military occupation, the Tennessee Capitol Building eventually came to be known as Fort Andrew Johnson due to the mounting fortications that built up around it. The Parrot Guns that are pictured in the image were capable of sending a projectile one mile. The eight gas lamps made by Wood and Perrot of Philadelphia were positioned at the Capitol entrance staircases and had at their bases cast iron figures representing morning, noon, and night.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Ingenious devices of soldiers in the camp and on campaign
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Inventions; Soldiers; Prisoners; Signaling; Water carriers; Shelters; Artillery (Weaponry); Equipment; Carts & Wagons; Military camps; Tents
Inventions; United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Fifteen images illustrating the imaginative way that Civil War soldiers tackled a variety of transportation, housing, equipment, and survival issues. Engravings on the back of the page appeared in Frank Leslie's post-war volume "The Soldier in Our Civil War," but they most probably premiered in "Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper" during the actual conflict. The origin of this illustrated page is unclear.

At the beginning of the Civil War, there were already millions of subscribers to Northern newspapers in the country. People had responded warmly to the amazing wood-cut illustrations of "Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper," and soon competitors like "Harper's Weekly" and "New York Illustrated News" emerged to imitate Leslie's combination of graphics and written news. The quality of the artwork varied greatly, and conveying accurate military news graphically proved challenging.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Mary Burnett to Jacob Burnett on "Liberty and Union, Now and Forever" stationery
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Flags
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Letters
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter from Mary Burnett to her husband Jacob Burnett discussing a ring she made, an incident in Warsaw, Kentucky, where two Federal men were nearly hanged, and the death of William Kittle. Offers to send him newspapers and clothing and asks if he will be home for the winter. Stationery features a female figure resembling Lady Liberty with an American flag.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Burnett, Mary
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Jacob J. Burnett was a Federal infantryman who served in the 7th Regiment of the Indiana Infantry. He enlisted September 13, 1861, and was discharged with a disability on March 24, 1863.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Then conquer we must
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Stationery; Letterheads
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter by Jacob J. Burnett on Federal stationery with the following quote: "Then conquer we must, when our cause it is just, and this be our motto -'In god is our trust,' " taken from fourth stanza of the Star-Spangled Banner. Above the quote is a woman holding wheat with her other hand on a shield.

In 1861, Jacob J. Burnett enlisted in the Civil War as a Federal soldier. After suffering wounds in mid-1862, he was hospitalized in the U. S. General Hospital in West Philadelphia, Pennsylvania, for several months before returning to Indiana.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from J. Wes Broom to Miss G. A. Brigham featuring drawings
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Ships; Flags
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Tennessee - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Stewart County (Tenn.); Port Hudson (La.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter from J. Wes Broom to Miss G.A. Brigham describing the fighting around Port Hudson. It describes a night battle with Federal ships and the effectiveness of the Confederate batteries positioned in the fort. There are also comments on scientific study, botany and astronomy. The letter includes two color drawings, one of men manning a cannon, and the other of a Federal side-wheeler in flames.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Brown, J. Wes
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The Confederates held Port Hudson until July 1863. A siege by Federal ships and troops eventually wore down the defenders and 6,500 Confederate troops surrendered. The port was captured and the Federals won control of the Mississippi River.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Letter from Jacob Burnett to Mary Burnett featuring a color plate of General McClellan
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Flags; Horses
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Letters; McClellan, George Brinton, 1826-1885
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Letter from Jacob Burnett to his wife Mary, written from his hospital bed, commenting on the state of the Federal army. It chastises the Federal army's behavior and some of its leadership. He sends his love to his wife and children and requests more frequent letters from his family. Stationery features a plate of Gen. McClellan in front of troops with the words "The War for the Union." Burnett has struck out the word "Union."
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Burnett, Jacob
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Jacob J. Burnett was a Federal infantryman who served in the 7th Regiment of the Indiana Infantry. He enlisted September 13, 1861, and was discharged with a disability on March 24, 1863.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: Rates of Postage in the Confederate States of America
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Postage Stamps

United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Postage Stamps; Printing on Postage Stamps; Portraits on Postage Stamps; Postage Stamp Design; Heraldry on Postage Stamps; Birds on Postage Stamps; Handstamps (Philately)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Description of the rates of postage in the Confederate States of America from pages 58-61 of the 1862 "Confederate States Almanac." Describes the amount of postage needed for various items, distances, and locations. Features images of 58 different stamps.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Clarke, H. C.
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: The original almanac was published in 1861 in Vicksburg, Mississippi. This facsimile was published in 1895. First page states 25% of net proceeds will be donated to the Confederate Veterans Camp of Atlanta, Georgia.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: An Incident of General Sherman's March Through Georgia
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Horses; Flags; Houses
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Georgia - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Sherman, William T. (William Tecumseh), 1820-1891
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color engraving of Union soldiers being greeted at a plantation home. An African Amreican family can be seen on the right, a group of women and children stand at the top of the stairs of the house.

The "Illustrated London News" was a magazine founded by Herbet Ingram and Mark Lemon. The magazine typically had sixteen pages and thirty-two wood engravings of various popular, contemporary topics. Sherman's march to the sea was a slash and burn action conducted in late 1864. The path of destruction went from Atlanta, Georgia, to Savannah.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The War in Tennessee: First Landing of the U.S. Troops in Tennessee
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Horses; Steamboats
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Fort Henry, Battle of, Tenn., 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Engraving of soldiers, equipment, and supplies being off-loaded from steamboats onto shore as seen from the deck of one of the ships. Columns of soldiers and horses, barrels, and wagons can be seen on the shore. Engravings of Major-General James A. Garfield and General Simon Bolivar Buckner are at the top of the page.

Frank Leslie was an English-American engraver who published numerous periodicals. "Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper," later called "Frank Leslie's Weekly," was a popular magazine featuring prints, images, and photographs of contemporary events. The fall of Fort Henry opened the Tennessee River to Federal gunboats.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The War in Tennessee: The Approach of the U.S. Gunboats to Fort Henry
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Forests; Boats
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Fort Henry, Battle of, Tenn., 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Engraving shows the approach of U. S. Gunboats to Fort Henry. Two Confederate ironclads can be seen at the right of the image. An engraving of R. E. A. Kimball and Maj. Gen. Ulysses S. Grant are featured below the image.

Frank Leslie was an English-American engraver who published numerous periodicals. "Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper," later called "Frank Leslie's Weekly," was a popular magazine featuring prints, images, and photographs of contemporary events. Fort Henry's fall opened the Tennessee River to Federal gunboats.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The Campaign in Tennessee: Interior of Fort Henry on the Morning after its Capture
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Boats; Flags; Horses
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Fort Henry, Battle of, Tenn., 1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Engraving from "Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper" of the interior of Fort Henry showing groups of soldiers, tents, and the rampart walls. A small image of Camp Chase, Ohio, is also shown under the larger image of Fort Henry.

Frank Leslie was an English-American engraver who published numerous periodicals. "Frank Leslie's Illustrated Newspaper," later called "Frank Leslie's Weekly," was a popular magazine featuring prints, images, and photographs of contemporary events. Camp Chase was a Confederate prison camp located near Columbus, Ohio. More than two thousand prisoners are buried in the camp cemetery.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: The "Grand Skedaddle" of the Inhabitants from Charleston, S.C., when Threatened by and Attack from the Federal Troops
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Soldiers; Dogs
United States - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Charleston (S. C.) - History - Civil War, 1861-1865; Charleston (S. C.)
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Print of Charleston citizens with their children, pets, livestock, and possessions fleeing the city. A description of the event is featured below the image.

Description reads: When General Brannan made his daring and successful dash upon the railroad between Pocotaligo & Coosawhatchie the terror in both Savannah and Charleston was very great. Despite the fact that General Beauregard with 30,000 troops was stationed midway between the cities a restless desire for flight took possession of thousands and for three days the roads to the interior were crowded.

oai_dc:dc.dc:title: In camp near Shiloh
oai_dc:dc.dc:rights: While TSLA houses an item, it does not necessarily hold the copyright on the item, nor may it be able to determine if the item is still protected under current copyright law. Users are solely responsible for determining the existence of such instances and for obtaining any other permissions and paying associated fees that may be necessary for the intended use.
oai_dc:dc.dc:subject: Military training; Military maneuvers; Military headquarters; Military uniforms; Military rations; Sutlers
Shiloh, Battle of, Tenn., 1862; United States--History--Civil War, 1861-1862
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: Color lithograph of the 1st Regiment, Kentucky Infantry, in camp before the battle of Shiloh. The lithograph is based on a drawing by a soldier in the regiment. Pictured are tents, military equipment, and soldiers involved in various activities, including conversation, cooking, and playing cards.
oai_dc:dc.dc:creator: Chapman, Conrad Wise
oai_dc:dc.dc:description: This lithograph is based on a drawing made by Conrad Wise Chapman, a young American who was raised in Europe. It is a scene in a Confederate camp at Corinth, Mississippi, just prior to the battle of Shiloh. Chapman was a member of the 1st Kentucky Regiment, also known as Wise's Brigade, and was badly wounded at Shiloh. He is considered the most important artist of the Confederacy.
